boat.full_description:
Motor lifeboat Hilda was built at the Niestern shipyard in Delfzijl in 1922 and named after the wife of the North and South Dutch Rescue Company (NZHRM) secretary H. de Booy. During her active service as a lifeboat she sailed 411 times and 540 people were rescued. In 1929 the boat was extended by 1.30 m and the 15 cm rubber fender was installed all around. Until 1930 the Hilda was in service around the isle of Schiermonnikoog with skipper Mees Toxopeus, and after this she moved to the Lemmer station before leaving the service in 1975. Once out of active service the Hilda was converted into a 2 masts sailing yacht, with a cruising ground that stretched from the Isle of Wight to Copenhagen. About 2002 the boat was completely stripped and fitted with a new engine. She was found in deplorable condition in 2008 and converted into a pleasure yacht at the yard S.R.F in Harlingen. Since then, trips have been made with the Hilda in European inland and coastal waters. Her current owners purchased her in 2018, giving her a "technical update" which involved renewing the mast and plates in the hull, installing motor inside cooling, and a second plotter and VHF. In 2021 Hilda sailed to Oslo-Norway. Hilda is registered with the Nautical Association Olde Resque Glory.

Length Originally 14.20 m, width 3.90 m, draft 0.90 cm, Now 15.50/4.25/1.10-1.20 m Displacement 23 tonnes, 15 watertight compartments. Now 27 tonnes and 3 watertight compartments.

First engine a 3 cylinder Bronze crude oil engine of 48 hp, replaced by a Kromhout 53 hp. Now a 6 cylinder Mitsubishi 130 hp. Max speed 8 knots.
